Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Origin and Role of Dense Molecular Gas in Star-Forming Galaxies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The team will use the Robert C. Byrd Green Bank Telescope (GBT) to observe the dense gas in nearby galaxies. The team has added a cutting-edge instrument, Argus, to this NSF facility. This has paved the way for these important observations at millimeter wavelengths. The team will study how galaxies form stars in their dense gas. They will compare their observations to theoretical models. Senior team members will train junior members recruited from underrepresented groups. The team will feature the research in materials for the Bay Area Science Festival in California and the Green Bank Visitors Center in West Virginia. The team will also help others use Argus for their own research.

The team will use Argus on the GBT to map the dense molecular gas in nearby galaxies at high spatial resolution. They will combine these new data with existing data at other wavelengths to study (1) how the amount of star formation per unit of dense gas depends on the local conditions in the galaxies, and (2) how the amount of dense gas depends on the local conditions in the galaxies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Stars form from dense concentrations of molecular gas but the exact relationship between the amount of dense gas and the amount of star formation is not clear. The aim of this proposal was to investigate this relationship by measuring the density of the gas in nearby galaxies and relating it to the star formation activity. Some molecules present in the gas from which stars form can emit radio waves if the gas is above a treshold density. So, by measuring the radio waves from these molecules, we can estimate the density of the gas.

To make these measurements, we used Argus, a camera sensitive to radio emission around 100 GHz, on the Green Bank Telescope. We have completed the second out of three observing seasons. The data quality obtained thus far has met expectations and no instrumental problems have been reported. We have done three internal releases as we work to improve our data reduction pipeline. We are currently preparing for data release 1 which will include HCN, HCO+, 13CO, and C18O maps for 9 galaxies, plus HCN and HCO+ maps for one additional galaxy.  

The students and postdocs that worked on this project have gained valuable hands-on experience with observational radio astronomy, helping to develop a pipeline for a new instrument.
